is a small - former - mining town in the Enns valley part of
), that is now a very popular large winter sports resort. It has a great view on the Dachstein mountains.

The population of Schladming is only 4,367 (2012) inhabitants, but because it is a well-known European winter sports resort during the season it is swarming with tourists from home and abroad. It held the 2013 FIS Alpine World Ski Championships.

Planai is the most important mountain with many ski routes and the other popular place for skiers is Hochwurzen.

Several shops and boutiques are located within the city limits and many restaurants, so called 'hüttes' is located all around the city, mostly on the slopes.

value: content=The tourist office is helpful to find an appropriate accommodation plus it also lists all upcoming events.

The closest international airport is the
is approximately 300km away. Alternatively there is the smaller
Airport (SZG), which is served by Austrian Airlines, Lufthansa and Ryanair, as well as other major carriers.

ÖBB serves high capacity trains to the train station that belongs to the "Ennstalbahn" (Salzburg - Bischofshofen - Schladming - Selzthal - Bruck - Graz route). The train station got modernised in 2011/2012. Schladming can be reached by night trains with a single stop in Munich. The trains take 4:10 hours from Vienna, 2:40 hours from Graz, 3:00 hours from Linz, 1:30 hours from Salzburg (add 1:40 hours for the link to Munich), and 3:00 hours from Innsbruck.
Schladming can be reached by car within an hour from Salzburg Airport, 2 hours from
and from the Italian border, 3 hours from Switzerland, 12 hours from Denmark. Beware of possible winterly road conditions when planing the road trip.
The inner old town of Schladming is small and easily traversed by foot. For skiing their are lots of lifts connecting the different mountains.

value: File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-09245, Österreich, Skitruppen beim Manöver.jpg
Austrian Alpine Hunters on exercise at Schladming in 1930 with Dachstein background
image=Bundesarchiv Bild 102-09245, Österreich, Skitruppen beim Manöver.jpg

content=The Dachstein Mountains are a mountain range in the Alps with its highest peak, the Hoher Dachstein (2,995 m). The area Dachstein Krippenstein is a hot spot for the ski/snowboard free rider scene. During summer lots of paths or climbing opportunities are to be found in this mountains.
content=The palais was built in 1884 by prince August zu Sachsen-Coburg-Gotha. The villa was used as hunting castle. During the German National-socialistic regime in 1940 it was bought by the town.

content=It was built in 1661 as social service place for the miners. In 1989 it opened as museum documenting the mining past of Schladming. The Ehrlich collection shows minerals and fossils. Next to it is a garden with traditional farmer tools.
content=The gate dating back to 1629 is part of the former old town fortifications.

content=The Schladming 4 Mountain Ski Link has 123 kilometres of slopes, It is also united with the even bigger nearby ski ressorts the Salzburg's Sports World, Gastein, Hochkönig and the Großarltal. There are several ski lodges for lunch or afternoon breaks (see the Eat section). The ski ressort Planai features a modern infractructure including comfortable high speed lifts. There are plenty of long and wide runs.

content=The place offers 3 different pools including a sports pool and a waterfall. There is a 66m tobogan and several different sauna to relax body and spirit. The gym has a wide range of courses such as strength-endurance circles, body styling, cardiovascular or step workout, power yoga, indoor cycling, Pilates and Zumba.
content=The ski school in Schladming teaches kids, teenagers and adults on the ski mountains Hochwurzen and Planai. They also offer individual lessons.
content=A school that combines sportive ski element with the usual education.
directions=The ski school at the Planai is located at the Weitmooshutte.

content=The school teaches kids and adults. Guided by experienced ski instructors beginners will perform their first turns on snow. More experienced skiers will be shown the way to a better style and technique.
name=Schladming Winter School for Theoretical Physics

content=The yearly held school attracts theoretical physicist since 50 years from around the world. Among the long list of famous lecturers are J.D. Björken, S.L. Glashow, M. Gell-Mann, A. Salam, B. Simon, W. Thirring, B. Zumino and so on. For the local people the meeting participants are known as the "Kernphysiker".

Schladming cannot compete with worldwide fashion scenes, but they offer interesting articles for skiers, as well as some sports articles. Several big supermarkets are also located within the city.
- just outside the city, in Pichl - offer groceries at a discount and are often the cheapest option in the area. In the very heart of the city you will find Billa and Spar. You can find
at the Planet Planai or at the train station.

is located at the highway, just a minute walk from Planet Planai and some hundred metres from the parking space. Billa and Spar offer the same groceries at almost the same prices. Both a butcher and a bakery is to find inside the two stores.

value: content=The worldwide famous ski and snowboard retailer - resides in Schladming. Here you can visit their largest flagship store, just a throw away from the main street.
content=The former ski champion and ski trainer of the Austrian ski team has a ski shop where he lends skis or sells ski sport clothes.
content=The owner has first hand experience and hence the shop is specialised on down hill and mountain biking.

A large amount of restaurants and cafés are located in the small old town, some are listed below. From the lodges
at Planai offers an relaxed atmosphere and some nice food.

at Hochwurzen offers a very high quality food, refusing to sell french fries and other very high calories food. A local speciality is the "Graukäse" cheese, which is a special "Steirerkas" and is eaten on bread or with "Nockerl".

value: content=The restaurant serves typical traditional regional Styrian food for very resonable price. There is limited choice and a daily lunch menu. The traditional restaurant got refurbished with modern decor. It used to be a butcher shop.
content=A cheap restaurant serving an Austrian interpretation of Italian food. Don't expect also too much service.

content=The hut from the "Naturfreunde" welcomes guests with Styrian specialities like "Käsenocken" with "Graukäse". They have different good "Schnaps" choices. The view from the hut is breath taking. It is nicely oriented for the sun and protected by the sourounding mountains.
content=Traditional good Austrian food is served with regional products. The walls are decorated with crafted wood panels. The restaurant has a big event hall.
content=Next to the start of many hiking path this old farmer house serves traditional food. The portions are big.
directions=hidden in the back of the old town

content=The Austrian restaurant serves regional specialities from Styria. The current tenant/cook owns the place for more than 20 years. The place fills up quickly, hence it is advisable either to reserve in advance or be really early. On demand the Ennstaler Kasnock'n are made. For dessert the homemade Kaiserschmarrn is delicious.
content=The fancy restaurant serves international Mediterranean type of food. As the name indicates the décor uses wood for modern design.
content=The restaurant inside of the hotel serves Styrian specialities and can accommodate quite some peoples. They also offer good wines.

The local brewery was founded in 1909 and is partly owned by the bigger Austrian brewing company Brau-Union. It produces yearly 35000hl. Most of it is the blond beer, famous is also the "Dachstein Naturbier", where all ingredients are organically grown. The "Knappengold-Pils" is a dark beer. Plus there exists also a light "Radler" (half beer mixed with lemonade). Most restaurants or bar will serve the "Schladminger" beer. During winter the town sees many tourists and there are several lively bars inside the town.

If one stays inside the old town there is no need for a car to reach the cable trains. Although cheaper recommendation are also found higher up on the way to the Planai middle station or on the other side of the valley.

value: content=The family friendly hotel got renovated in 2013. It features comfortable rooms with parquet floors, recreation rooms, an internet terminal, a ping pong table, a ski room, a sauna, and a café serving small snacks.
content=This modest bed and breakfast is located directly inside Schladming.
content=The familial bed and breakfast has a bit outdated decor, but is located directly inside Schladming next to the river. Breakfast is included.
price=winter double room €130-280, summer €110-170 per person
content=The hotel is a traditional 4star hotel near Schladming. The spacious wellness alpine spa offers sauna areas and various pools.
content=The hotel opened in December 2012 right next to the Planai-Hochwurzen cable car. It offers a spa area, free Wi-Fi, a restaurant, free garage parking and a supermarket on the ground floor.
content=The four star hotel is next to the Reiteralm-planai ski slope with a direct view over the Enns Valley and the Dachstein mountains.

The ski ressort offers at several stations free Wi-Fi access.
The neighbour towns in the Enns valley are

value: is a 20 x 30 km limestone massif in the Northern Calcareous Alps with dozens of other peaks above 2,500 m.
is an alpine massif incorporating the national park Gesäuse.
is a popular ski and thermal bath health ressort in Salzburg.
is a popular ski ressort in Salzburg with links to the

is the fourth-largest city in Austria. Its "Old Town", with its world famous baroque architecture, is one of the best-preserved city centers in the German-speaking world and was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1997. There are direct trains taking 1.5 hours.
is the industrial and educational centre of Northern Styria and home of the Austrian mining industry and university. There are direct trains taking 1.5 hours.
